To point out to a sufferet that his misfortune is a common one does not bring conviction in every case. The truest remedy, but one not easy to apply while the annoyance is at its height, is that of Chrysippus, which consists in convincing the sufferer that his grief is due to his own volition‚ and to an idea that it is demanded by duty. We must vary our mode of treatment according to the person treated, ἓ 79. .

EPILOGUE. The discussion has digressed from the original question which was “Is the wise man affected by annoyance?’' Instead of dealing with that question we have discovered that the evil which is involved in annoyance results not from inevitable and necessary causes but from an act of will and erroneous opinion, ξ 80. Moreover we have dealt chiefly with one form of annoyance, grief for the dead (luctus), this being the severest of all its subdivisions, but the same treatment applies to all the rest, §g 81—4.
